Award.AwardTitle: MathBench Biology Modules: Expansion of Implementation and Assessment

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project is integrating MathBench Biology Modules, a series of interactive, web-based instructional modules, into the undergraduate biological sciences curriculum of a variety of institutions of higher education. The modules use humor, references to popular culture, and interactive elements to engage students and build upon their intuitive understanding in order to help them explore biological concepts using fairly sophisticated mathematical approaches. Work under a prior NSF CCLI Phase 1 grant developed the 37 modules and piloted them in four fundamental biology courses at the University of Maryland (UM) and one introductory biology course at Montgomery College(MC), a nearby community college. Assessment data from Phase 1 indicates that students using MathBench have a greater appreciation for the importance of mathematics in modern biology and show gains in quantitative proficiency that are independent of previous and current math coursework. This project expands implementation of the modules to 10 diverse collaborating institutions (2-year/4-year, public/private, research/primarily undergraduate, and majority/minority-serving). Activities include workshops to help participating faculty create implementation plans,and to aid in collection of assessment data and in dissemination at professional conferences. Collaborating faculty serve as peer consultants at future workshops in order to establish teaching and learning communities on a local scale (University System of Maryland 2- and 4-year institutions) and a national/international scale (universities participating in the Howard Hughes Medical Institute Quantitative Biology Consortium, a group committed to improving undergraduate education in quantitative aspects of biology). The modules are being evaluated and refined with respect to learning outcomes, student attitudes, and ease of implementation in pursuit of the ultimate goal of creating a faculty development framework to support dissemination.

Intellectual Merit: The project addresses a pressing national need by enhancing the interdisciplinary experiences of biological sciences undergraduates. The design of the modules addresses diverse learning styles and educational backgrounds, and their easy accessibility assures dissemination to a variety of educational contexts.

Broader Impacts: The project is producing well-tested educational modules that allow students from diverse educational backgrounds to hone their quantitative skills, preparing them for more complex mathematical approaches in upper-division courses and increasing their appreciation for the role of mathematics in modern biology. Collaborative assessment efforts are providing rich comparative data on how the modules affect student learning and attitudes across educational contexts, and are providing valuable information on how learner-centered, technologically-based pedagogies can be used to augment traditional instruction in STEM disciplines.

This project is being co-funded by the Directorate for Biological Sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
MathBench is a suite of 42 online modules that introduce and reinforce basic quantitative skills used in the biological sciences. This grant funded efforts to disseminate and evaluate MathBench modules at a broad range of institutions.  Our first goal was to expand the adoption of MathBench beyond the University of Maryland, where it was initially developed. We gave presentations on the modules and their use at a variety of scientific and science education conferences. These presentations broadened the community of MathBench users to over 50 institutions and led to invitations to give keynote presentations at international conferences in Australia and Germany. This is turn led to a collaboration with seven Australian universities, which received funding from the Australian government to adapt the modules for the Australian context, broadening the reach of MathBench to an international audience.

We held seven workshops in which university and community college faculty members learned about the modules and developed plans to incorporate the modules into their courses. Workshops were held at the University of Maryland, Howard County (MD) Community College, Emory University (Atlanta, GA), and University of Delaware and involved 83 faculty members. In addition to receiving training to develop their expertise in new methods of interdisciplinary teaching, workshop participants provided critical feedback on the usability of the modules and their content coverage, which was used to refine and expand this resource.

In collaboration with workshop participants, we conducted a comprehensive study of MathBench’s effectiveness in increasing undergraduate student quantitative skills and their appreciation for the role of mathematics in modern biology. Twenty-one faculty members from 13 institutions contributed data to this study. These faculty members administered surveys to their students at the beginning and end of the semester in which MathBench modules were used.

Students who liked math and reported making at least a moderate effort to answer questions correctly showed the largest gains in quantitative skill, while students who did not like math and reported making minimal effort to answer the questions showed little or no improvement. Therefore, our results showed that student scores on tests of quantitative skill were affected by their attitudes (e.g., the degree to which they like math) and the effort that they exerted in taking the test. This complicated our attempts to accurately measure student learning generally, and, more specifically, the impact of MathBench on student quantitative skills.

Improvement in quantitative skill after using MathBench varied between institutions and courses, but not in a systematic way (e.g., by type of institution, enrollment, level of course). Gains were correlated with scores on the pretest, indicating that those with stronger quantitative skills gain more from the modules than those with weaker quantitative skills. Students with the lowest level of mathematical proficiency only showed gains when they were also concurrently enrolled in a mathematics course. Student responses to open-ended survey questions indicated that the modules were most useful as a refresher for previously learned quantitative material and helped them contextualize the application of mathematics.

Although MathBench did not appear to affect attitudes toward mathematics or beliefs about the utility of mathematics in the biological sciences across a single semester, survey data from graduates of the University of Maryland showed that those who used MathBench during their undergraduate years had a greater appreciation for the importance of math than those who hadn’t used MathBench.
